title: Angular Watching depth
description: Performance and depth analysis of Angular's watching system.
author: Frank Bassard

content.value: Watching properties of the $scope is one of the core features of Angular. Most of the time this process is hidden and run in the background for you by the engine, but it's still common to have to use it manually.
Angular gives 3 way to watch a property depending on the depth required. The most depth you need, the less efficient is going to be the watch cycle.

Watching by reference is the most common and fastest way to watch an attribute. As JavaScript is sharing objects by reference, the reference watch is only going to be triggered when the whole reference changes.
Keep in mind that no change within the object will trigger the watch since the reference hasn't changed.
It's also the most common mechanism used by Angular, most of the build directives use reference watching (ngClass, ngModel, ngIf, ngShow, select ...)

Watching a collection is watching an ordered set of references. Creating, deleting or moving elements within the collection is going to trigger the watch but changes within objects of the collection isn't.
You can find that behaviour in a few native directives like ngRepeat.

Equality watches are looking for every change within the watched object, whatever the depth of the property. This process use the angular.equals mechanism which is comparing every field of an object to a copy of himself.
Keep in mind that using equality watches is the heavier type watch, use it only if you need an in-depth comparaison of your object.
